description.text:
Acrylic Electronics Mount Plate The Acrylic Mount Plate, for Prusa or Mendel design Reprap 3D printers, is capable of mounting RAMPS and/or Sanguinololu electronics.ï»¿ The mount plate is made of 5.5mm thick clear acrylic that allows for better viewing than wooden mounting plates. Also, you have no worries of slicing your arm open on a sharp acrylic corner as the plate has rounded edges. Specifications
-Capable of mounting RAMPS and/or Sanguinololu electronics
-5.5mm thick clear acrylic
-Size: 28cm x 9cm x 5.5cm
-Rounded corners Parts
-Acrylic electronics mount plate
-4x Printed mount bracket (elc_mount_bracket.stl) Other Vitamins
-4x 6.35mm stand-off spacer
-8x M3 35mm screws, nuts, and washers to mount the plate
-4x M3 screws to mount the electronics (length depends on your electronics) Licensing
-Parts and files: GPLv3
-Images: CC BY SA

• Acquire mount plate or cut with laser cutter or router.

  • Mount the mount plate to either the front or rear frame threaded rods using the mount brackets and 25mm M3 screws and nuts.

  • Mount your electronics to the mount plate with the stand-off spacers between the acrylic mount plate and bottom of the electronics board. RAMPS mounts to one side, Sanguinololu to the other (a soon updated version will be compatible with multiple electronics on either side).

Remixed to allow printing the brain and head separately, that way you can print the head in green and brain in pink if so desired =)
Hope you like it =)

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Notes: Need support for chin and lip area.

title: 360 Compact i3v E3d v6 50mm blower cooling fan mount

description.text: So, after being rather dissatisfied with the i3v blower fan mounts available, I decided to design my own. It's far from perfect, so please feel free to improve, but in it's current form, it works for me, so I thought I'd share. It's about as compact as you can get, fits around the stock hot end cooling fan, and it mounts on the front of the carriage, so it doesn't interfere with the side of the printer or bed clips as much as the wider ones. So far, I've printed my first one in PLA and it's been great, even when printing high temp stuff. I think simply by having the cooling fan on low keeps it cool enough not to melt. I plan on printing v2 in PET. The fan I bought for it can be found here: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00E4AAJ9O?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o09_s01 It mounts to the carriage using the standard wade exstruder fan mounting holes. I highly recommend tightening the attachment points well, this keeps the fan shroud level and rigid. Thanks and enjoy.

remixed_from.title: Parametric Cherry MX/Alps Keycap for Mechanical Keyboards

description.text:
This is a spacebar compatible with the Apple IIe keyboard. This is not an exact replica of the original spacebar (I have none to model from), but it is a usable replacement.
The original spacebar had mounting points for 3 keyswitches, although only the center one is actually used. The outer ones had a support sliver that were inserted into the mounting points. This version has the supports integrated.
There is a hole in each of these supports where a ~15AWG metal bar fits. This metal bar fits into clips mounted on the keyboard its self, and keeps the spacebar level when pressed off-center. If your keyboard is missing this metal bar, it can be constructed from 15AWG wire. 14AWG is more common, although the parts of the bar that mate with the clips will need to be sanded/filed down so the bar can rotate freely when clipped in.

author: byron99

title: Cooler for Wanhao Duplicator i3 stock fan

description.text:
EDIT - 09.12.2016:
Added a new version with changes to fit the Monoprice Select V2 printer. I made versions for 30 mm and 40 mm fans. Let me know in the comments if it doesn't fit. The blocks around the opening are supposed to be broken off after printing.

I made this cooler duct as an attempt to improve cooling with the stock 30mm fan since I don't have any other fans on hand. The 15-45 degree overhang test showed good improvement over the stock duct. It has a large volume and large openings to keep the fan from stalling. It can be installed with the original screws, no nuts required, but I recommend using slightly longer mounting screws for peace of mind.I used 8mm long screws. Take care when installing the screws, or run an M3 tap through the holes first. I was able to screw mine in directly. I printed mine from ABS with 0.2mm layers and external supports where the part hangs over the bed, as shown in one of the pictures picture. It's a tight fit around the hot end, but ABS is working fine. Strongly inspired by Pawpawpaw85s DiiiCooler: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1025471

• october 2015:
    I have uploaded a new version with thinner vanes, slightly smaller exit area and a continuation of the duct to block off the first vane to keep it from hogging all the air. Hopefully this will spread the air out more evenly. I'm printing mine as I write this. Thanks, to Pawpawpaw85s for tips on how to improve it.
    • TAHfan06 is the duct without supports.
    TAHfan06 - supports includes supports. The supports around the exit hole break off easilly. The ones under the inlet are tougher to break off, but the finish is never going to be that good under there anyway.

comments.text: Now I'm confused. Are you standing on the side of the printer when you say you stand in front of it? The four last photos the bottom of the photos is the left side of the printer.
comments.author: heytiger

comments.text: Please take a look at the photos and you will see what I'm talking about. Moving the mounting bracket closer to the intake duct, to the left, and slightly up will make it fit.
comments.author: tahustvedt

comments.text: Download the test_repaired.stl file and look at it in your slicer. It has both the new and old bracket for comparison. If it looks ok I will make one with the new.
comments.author: heytiger

comments.text: Here's the printed test, and it's nearly perfect! The height is just right for it to mount flush, as you can see in the middle photo. I think we went a little too far moving the holes half a millimeter closer, as it now sits slightly askew as you can see in the last photo. I'm not sure how it's got to move to repair the slight skewing we're seeing in the first photo. Overall, this is the best fit for the new monoprice printer. Thank you so much for working with me on this!
comments.author: tahustvedt

comments.text: OK. I uploaded new ducts with the new position now.
comments.author: heytiger

comments.text: Thanks so much!
comments.author: tahustvedt

comments.text: For other users: This does not work for the Monoprice select v2. While it is a rebranded duplicator i3, they appear to have used a larger fan and higher bracket. Large modifications would be required for it to fit
comments.author: evilvargon

comments.text: Hey! I got the newest one printed and installed, I'm not sure if it works that well but I have done two prints that look great! I noticed air comes out the back of the fan, is there too much pressure from the fan or should I decrease the speed?

comments.text: Would it be insanity to print this with PLA?
comments.author: zolan

comments.text: I think it'll work fine. I usually print my duct in PLA first for testing.
comments.author: zolan

comments.text: My only concern would be if it was close enough to the nozzle to melt but I suppose it already has air flowing through it to keep it cool-ish.
comments.author: tahustvedt

comments.text: It cools the right side of the nozzle way more than the left side. I should try evolving it. Still waiting for my blower. )

description.text:
3D Lab Print P51-D Mustang- motor conversion kit

  • this kit include modified nose section and motor mounts which allows you
    install most of the available brushless motors (or your own prop/motor/ESC/battery
    setup)
    BUT OF COURSE WE STILL RECOMMEND OUR SETUP AS THE BEST

  • please notice:
    if you need use crossmount (f.e. if you need isolate heat from motor) you will
    need modify nose section of fuselage with soldering iron or some hot tool. Remember
    that crossmount 42x42 is suitable mainly for bigger models than Spitfire

title: big tea cup which I like a lot

description.text:
this is a big tea cup which I like a lot, and if it can be made by glass, it would be great.   
did anyone try to print it?

comments.text:
I tried printing this and aborted as the bottom of the cup did not print, so it would have a problem holding water! I printed in PLA 0.2mm thick and solid infill as I wanted it to be watertight. The big hole in the bottom cancelled that out :-)
Looked at the STL file and it is very thin at the bottom with a strange T-structure that looks like it is there to support the bottom of the cup bowl.
I was printing with both rafts and supports using MakerWare.
The STL file probably needs adjusting to make a thinker base.
comments.author: gkewley

First version of Pi camera. I was not able to find a good camera support with pan and tilt functionalities so I made one. Please not this thing requires some amount of tinkering (soldering, connecting electronic components, etc). I also wrote a short post with link to Github repository on my blog.
Let me know what you think! KNOWN ISSUES:
1/ the camera flat cable is not the best choice for pan and tilt applications. So far worked well nonetheless. The design is already compatible with a round cable.
2/ requires a thin tool like a screw driver to access the SD card release mechanism. This will be solved in further releases

BoM
  • 30 cm FPC camera ribbon (http://www.ebay.ch/itm/Ribbon-FPC-15pin-1mm-Pitch-30cm-flat-Wire-Cable-for-Raspberry-Pi-Camera-Module-/271557924455?hash=item3f3a1d1667)
    Raspberry Pi
  • DC Power Apply Pinboard 5.5x2.1mm Adapter Plate (http://www.ebay.ch/itm/DC-Power-Apply-Pinboard-5-5x2-1mm-Adapter-Plate-/370890293427?hash=item565ac8c0b3)
  • LM2596 Step Down Module DC-DC Buck Converter (http://www.ebay.ch/itm/LM2596-Step-Down-Module-DC-DC-Buck-Converter-Power-Supply-Output-1-23V-30V-New-/251066005460?hash=item3a74b337d4)
  • SG 90 servos (http://www.ebay.ch/itm/10pcs-SG90-9G-micro-servo-motor-RC-Robot-Helicopter-Airplane-controls-/400980196653?hash=item5d5c483d2d)
  • nuts, bolts and wires

Basically you need a power regulator to ensure a steady supply for the Raspberry Pi and the servos plus a power distribution board (big name, just 3 lines of a prototype board will do). Below some pictures of my setup.

This is a simple bending spring foot that dampens the conducted vibrations from your printer to whatever surface it's standing on. These feet clip onto any M8 threaded or smooth rod. It is extremely effective at decoupling low frequency noise from a surface. The feet have holes for permanent mounting on a surface. Also, as my printer is pretty heavy, these feet are very strong and will easily support a heavy prusa i3 with filament reel on top. The clips are very snug and secure. In order to dampen higher frequency noise as well, add a little bit of PU insulation material (foam) under the foot as shown in the application image. The combination of 4 of these feet and the insulation material made that I cannot hear the printer anymore behind a door. Airborne noise is already blocked pretty well by the door, but without the feet, the table it's standing on as well as my floor acted like a sound board. Other spring feet, like vector's feet (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:21855) didn't fit my printer. The model is designed in CATIA, CATPart file can be downloaded and modified if you wish.

Printing tips: I printed mine with PLA, 0.35mm nozzle, 0.25mm layer height, hexagonal fill 40% on Marlin firmware. Firmware with curve look-ahead (like Marlin) is highly recommended, as the feet derive much of their strength and flexibility from the continuous curve of the perimeters.

The film rewind crank for the Pentax MV is quite brittle, it will fell apart sooner or later...
... so I replaced it with a knob, which is glued with the shim. The knob will work nicely to rewind the film but you may use the crank for your convenience.
In order to view the pictures, please enlarge them.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Step by step.
  • Glue the shim to the knob.
  • Use a file to make a prober finish on the knob.
  • Use the screw from the original crank and attach the knob to the camera.
  • Optional, glue a patch of camera leather to the knob.
  • When you are about to rewind the film, just press the crank on the knob.

title: Air mixer handle for jewellery torch

description.text: I made this handle for the air mixer on our jewellery torches at the school.  The pupils sometimes found it difficult to turn the screw valve.  There is a lock ring on the mixer that on occasion was locked unintentionally resulting in stripping the threads of the mixer and ruining it.  This handle allows for more torque, and hides the lock ring so it cannot be locked unintentionally.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm layers

Infill:

100% (solid)

Notes: I printed this using our Velleman K8200 printer. I printed it solid to give it more strength, and to make sure the grub screw threads had enough support behind them.

After the printing After the print had cooled down, I drilled out the pilot hole to 4.2mm to receive a 5mm tap. I then hand tapped a M5 thread to facilitate a grub screw to hold the handle onto the mixer.

This is a small variation on my original customizable Origami Ship. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:753562 Travelling in Greece this year, I kept spotting the origami ship in gift shops in various forms and materials. However they looked slightly different. I realized that typically they had a quadrilateral side in place of two triangles. The revised design looks cleaner than the original I think. It is slower to render because calculating the 4th point in the quadrilateral requires iterative computation of a determinant. see http://kitwallace.tumblr.com/post/125590768269/the-ubiquitous-origami-ship.

title: First Y-axis Driving Test using by linear stepping motor.

description.text:
I did Y-axis moving test.
The results was not good. The maximum speed was just about 55 mm/sec.
The linear stepping motor was stalled when it over 55 mm/sec. The linear thread is not straight and it is directly affect to the z-direction accuracy on this type structure.
It makes z-direction waving of bed plate when it move.
I didn't know the possibility of the linear thread would be not straight. Please refer following link movie.
http://youtu.be/YwmH_hrgCt4 The uploaded file is the y-end idler.
It was slightly modified for more good fit.
The original model was in the following link.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:104525

comments.text: Is this Y idler better overall, or because your threads were bent?
comments.author: evamvid

comments.text: I think the most serious problem is the bending of the linear screw. And the work of fixing the bending is a time consuming work. Furthermore, because of the short lead length, high friction on the nut, so it was hard to make the speed over 100 mm/sec.
comments.author: evamvid

comments.text: If the screw came straight, would this idler still work better?
comments.author: jspark

comments.text: Sure, there's no problem on this idler.
comments.author: evamvid

comments.text: I know it's desirable to use as many printed part as possible, but an anti-backlash nylon nut would work best in this situation.  You can reduce the noise on those quick moves by fiddling with the Jerk and acceleration settings in your firmware.
comments.author: wildseyed

comments.text:
Thanks for good comments wildeyed!
The motor and lead screw is not separated.
It was unthinkable that the lead screw would not straight too.
Could you let me know where can I get the anti-backlash nylon nut?
I hope it is not expensive.
comments.author: wildseyed

comments.text: I did wonder what the max speed would be, you'd either need to gear it up, or get something like a 30mm pitch leadscrew, to allow higher speeds, or use lower microstepping. (although by using any of these, your printer resolution would go down)
comments.author: Aggresive

comments.text: Thanks for good comment!
comments.author: Aggresive

author: jspark

description.text: An OpenSCAD module for writing variable-width text. Download Spiff.scad and spiffsans.scad, then see the Instructions for how to use this in your own works (or use poorman-spiff to generate a copy-pasteable demo). Spiff.scad on GitHub

Spiff.scad requires at least OpenSCAD 2013.06, as it uses module recursion to calculate variable glyph widths. If you're stuck on an older version of OpenSCAD, you can still generate the equivalent code for writing text using poorman-spiff. Due to OpenSCAD's recursion limit, you may encounter problems writing longer strings. If this happens, try breaking your write call up into multiple calls with shorter strings.

Note that, while this is listed as a derivative of Write.scad, it is not derivative code, and is almost completely incompatible (they're almost compatible in the sense that they both write text, but that's it).

Draws a group of 2D polygons for the given string, using the given font (see section on Fonts, below). Glyphs are spaced apart by the value of the third "spacing" parameter (1 unit by default). By default, if no font is specified, Spiff Sans will be used. (spiffsans.scad should be included in the same directory as Spiff.scad.) These 2D polygons can be transformed in 3D space using the regular OpenSCAD transformations in combination with linear_extrude.
use <Spiff.scad>; write("Variable width text"); translate([0,-12,0]) linear_extrude(height=4) write("Simple as anystring"); See spiff-examples for more examples of Spiff.scad in use.

See the readme on GitHub for documentation of the font structure used by Spiff.scad. Converters for various font formats to this font representation are being developed at https://github.com/stuartpb/spaggers .

comments.text: Both "a" and "A" are displayed as "A". The data for both capital and lower case glyph of every letter are the same.  It seems that this package only draws capital fonts  :(
comments.author: runsun

comments.text: This package can draw mixed-case fonts- it's just that the default font, Spiff Sans, as I drew it, is an all-caps font, as it was designed for industrious, functional text. You're welcome to contribute your own lower-case letterforms.
comments.author: runsun

comments.text: Awesome, I can't wait to try this! On a feature request note, the one fancy function in Write.scad that I actually used a lot was WriteCylinder. It's vastly more convenient than placing each letter individually (especially with variable-width). If you could implement something like that, it would be spectacular.
comments.author: emmett

comments.text: I thought about that. What I ultimately figured was that the functionality of write_cylinder would be better served by something like a general cylindrical transformation module, or a Minkowski sum, or the intersection of a long linear extrusion with a cylinder. (I don't know how to do a cylindrical transformation myself, though.)
comments.author: emmett

My entry to the ThinkFun challenge, this part allows you to connect your projects to a soda bottle.
I build this around the standard 28mm bottle cap compatible with most common soft drinks  small, medium and large bottles.
You could fill a bottle with water or sand and use it as a weighted stand, you could use the smaller sized bottles as extra chunky - go anywhere wheels, or you could add bottles as floats or pontoons and make your projects amphibious!
I looked at several connection options but in the end decided that simply adding a 1inch rod to the cap made the most sense and was the easiest to print and use.
The model prints really well with no support and no raft, it came off the build platform with a little tap.
I could not find an exact measurement for the rod, but I settled on 7.4mm (easily adjusted).
Enjoy!

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm layer 0.5mm nozzle

Infill:

20%

Notes: Needed about 5g of plastic, I printed in ABS and it came out perfect first time.
I sanded off a few burrs but it didn't need any finishing really.

I was already working on a bottle cap for another project, it had taken me some trial and error to get it right and I fiddled with the thread to make sure it would print well without support.
The rod was simply added to the top of the bottle (simple designs are always the best), I did add a core inside the cap to remove any need for support this also adds strength to the design.
The walls were originally 2mm think but I halved that it is still very strong.
I did the whole thing in sketchup, all my circles have 96 facets and my designs are all in metric.
I printed several prototypes so I could play with them and make sure the cap fit well.

description.text:
I wanted to create a simple support for the Y axis motor since the 1.5 mm plate was bending under belt tension. Works in combination with the stock plate. No interference with the V wheels as the part is the same width as the maker slide. Designed to work with my Y Support foot http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:106163
  • Note this part has been dimensioned specifically for the standard Nema 17 Stepper motor which comes with the current RepRapDiscount Kit. (Motor Height should measure 39 mm high from base to top motor cap) Please measure before printing.
    • As requested I have added a support designed for the automationtechnologies kit with their 47 mm high motor. I did not have the motor to physically dimension so please let me know if it doesn't work! Please comment below if you need additional sizes

• Print (Printed with 3 perimeter passes, 0.2mm layer height, 20% infill)

  • Remove Y motor and insert 2 M5 t nuts into bottom of maker slide.

  • Re-attach motor with stock plate.

  • Nest motor cables in recessed slot of the support and fasten to rail with m5 10mm bolt.

  • Tension belt as needed!

title: 250x150x4 mm Chopping Glass holder for Replicator

description.text:
I found such a thing in a store for 1.49 EUR and I couldn't resist to give it a try.  
It works amaizingly well (with some limitations) together with the cheapest strong fix hairspray (Laca Isabel: 2.09 EUR in the same store).  
This thing is not parametric, sorry.  
I have no idea if it could be suitable for other printers than the Replicator Dual where I am using it.

Mind the zero height of the Z stage!!  
Because the glass (I got) is 4mm thick you'll need to either install the build platform 4mm lower or trigger the Z end-stop 4 mm earlier! I use some glue and a 4mm piece of wood in the back of the Z stage.  
Limitations: for a Replicator Dual, the clips are in the (possible) way of the nozzels!! Extra care has to be taken at zeroing the Z (start of each print). I just place the clip in the right-back corner some 10mm to the front.  
Use ABS! and give it an acetone/acetone-vapor bath.  
The parts will warp due to the heat of the build platform but this should no be severe enough to have any bad consequence.  
Do not use PLA! unless you'll never use the heated build platform.

author: gustaveband

title: Pc Case Mod - Round Window with LED

description.text: A window frame for your PC Case, with options to use LED to light up the inside of the case.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

30%

Instructions To cut the hole in the Case use the outer_ring as a template.
You can use clear glass or plexi for the window, 1-3mm should work fine. (I'm using 2mm plexi in my build)
you can print the inner ring in clear PLA or ABS if you want the inner ring to glow from the 5 5mm led mounted on the ring. If you don't want to use led then print the "inner_ring_clean.stl" instead off the "inner_ring_led.stl".
Each led are connected in serial with a resistor ( 100 ohm for Blue/green led and 150 ohm for red/yellow led, this is for "standard 5mm" led 1.8-3V). the 5 led:s are connected to each other in parallel and have a 5v feed from the PC power supply . you can buy led witch are ready for 5 or 12 V if you don't want to use a resistor.
The ribs a just a bonus if you want some easy decoration, print and cut the rib to suite your length of each rib and glue them to the case.
If you print the rib in clear plastic you can hide 3mm led or a thin led strip in the ribs slot and get a nice glowing effect.
20150910 : Another version off the inner ring led part, this one with holder for cable management .

author: xxX_LilStruggle_Xxx

description.text:
Pincette for lense
I print on solidoodle
layer 0.2mm
temperature 195 one 20mm
two 10mm

Great design but for 1515 profile I had 2020 profile so amended and resized to use 2020. Now up and running will be posting any improvements I make as I tune and adjust performance. I have made printer somewhat larger and intending a 300x300x400 print area up to 500mm height if possible. The printer is fairly large internal frame dimensions are 360x500 external dimensions with protrusions about 500x600mm height will be approx 600mm. Still checking all calculations and printing last pieces of main frame. Will keep updated as I go but if you begin printing before I have frame assembled, you may end up printing some parts twice. One or two edges may lack the refinement of original but thats down to the limitations of my knowledge and my use of TinkerCAD to do the conversion. As for my choice of color, I had a couple of KG of PLA sitting around with no plans, so loaded purple into my Wanhao i3 and Tangerine into my XYZ Da Vinci 2.0a may have been tri colored if I had built up the Delta I have sitting in a box to build while I wait for last few parts for this project to arrive from China. Cost of 2020 Profile about 5mtr from 2x3mtr Lengths as I built two Sardauscan Scanners from the remainder, (2 @ Bosch-Rexroth-Extrusion-Aluminium-Strut-Profile-6mm-Groove-3000mm-L-20x20mm from eBay UK at £19.80 a length 0r £6.60 per mtr delivered next day £39.60, 2kg PLA also Ebay UK £21.58, obviously nuts bolts etc most of which I had and the T Nuts Printed from (M4 T Slot nut by daGHIZmo, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1061769) Most of frame now assembled and found one flaw in my design, 500mm Uprights are going to have to be shortened by 50-75mm then I can put together cutting list for profile. 2020 Profile cutting list. [email protected] Crossmembers 2 Front and 2 Rear
[email protected] Side Horizontals
[email protected] Side Verticals
[email protected] Side Braces
[email protected] Top Crossmember Left and Right Top pieces being reworked as the support restricts usable height too much moving support inside to give extra print height. (DONE). Now reworking the XMotor and Xidler pieces to repair weaknesses(DONE). Now waiting on delivery of all metalwork and electronics so short break on this project
4x 500mm 8mm Linear Rod and 10x 8x15x24 linear Bearings
10x 8mm Bearing Mounts 6 for carriage Y axis and 4 for extruder X axis (X axis could be 3 but intended future upgrades will require fourth) 18/10 Turned Y access drive belt from vertical to horizontal for ease of access and fitting. 19/10 Bed construction mostly complete 300x300mm be able to print cases for the iPad Air rather than the phone. 20/10 Changed out the bearing mounts as they were over specified the fist assembly showed me how much friction was possible with a slight misalignment of any one so re designed simpler and more flexible carriers saving lots of filament and making printing easier. 3 sets required deliberately left no holes for bed base as these can be drilled through base and Y belt attachment as it makes easier assembly. 31/10
Y Belt attachment didn't adhere well when printed and lifted both ends used as did not matter center is mount ends only prevent twist. 31/10
X Carriage also amended printed in one fixing with cable ties will allow quick change for future mods laser, dremel etc. X Carriage replaced on 21/11 my bad, file control one I originally uploaded 2.75mm to long as I had to use a delta printer that I knew was printing short on the Y Axis and I adjusted to print forgot to delete that file First Print 20mm cube to check calibration, a bit of tuning to do but working after sorting out Repetier Firmware problem that was an Arduino Problem hanging onto the original values in the Eprom, should know better than to configure and print for the first time on Friday the 13th. Temporary heated bed waiting for 300mm to turn up so popped in a 220mm for testing. Changed the Bed carriage and y Belt attachment needed more height a little less flexibility and improved Belt fixing 20/11

description.text: A while ago my wife accidentally broke the mount that holds the garage door sensor to the metal mounting post.  Since then it's been held on there with tape and a zip tie.  So I decided to design and print a replacement.  I designed this in a way that it could be printed without supports and the mounting bracket part could be replaced / redesigned easily.  The mounting bracket is secured to the outer housing with glue.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

10%
After Printing Place glue along the joining seams and let glue dry.
This was designed in FreeCAD using the original bracket for measurements.
